The protooncogene <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a monomeric G protein family member , plays a critical role in converting extracellular signals into intracellular biochemical events .

Here , we report that nitric oxide ( NO ) activates <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in human T cells as evidenced by an increase in GTP - bound <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: In vitro studies using pure recombinant <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> demonstrate that the activation is direct and reversible .
Circular dichroism analysis reveals that NO induces a profound conformational change in <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in association with GDP / GTP exchange .
The mechanism of activation is due to S - nitrosylation of a critical cysteine residue which stimulates guanine nucleotide exchange .

Furthermore , we demonstrate that <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is essential for NO - induced downstream signaling , such as NF-kappa B activation , and that endogenous NO can activate <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the same cell .
These studies identify <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a target of the same cell .

These studies identify <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a target of NO in T cells and suggest that NO activates <extra_id_0> p21ras <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by an action which mimics that of guanine nucleotide exchange factors .
